title: Amos Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Amos chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Amos Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Amos Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who is the word in Amos 3:1 spoken against?
options: The children of Israel
The children of Judah
The Philistines
The Egyptians
questions.correctAnswer: The children of Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 3:1 states that the LORD hath spoken against the children of Israel, the whole family brought up from Egypt.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:2, why will the LORD punish Israel?
options: Because they only have He known of all families
Because they worship false gods
Because they have not built a temple
Because they have been too humble
questions.correctAnswer: Because they only have He known of all families
questions.explanation: Amos 3:2 says God will punish Israel because He only has known them of all the families of the earth.

questions.question: What question does Amos 3:3 ask about two walking together?
options: Can two walk together, except they be agreed?
Can two walk together without a guide?
Can two walk apart and still be friends?
Can two walk together in the dark?
questions.correctAnswer: Can two walk together, except they be agreed?
questions.explanation: Amos 3:3 asks if two can walk together except they be agreed, emphasizing agreement as necessary for companionship.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Amos 3:4: 'Will a lion roar in the forest, when he hath no ______?'
options: prey
den
mane
strength
questions.correctAnswer: prey
questions.explanation: Amos 3:4 asks if a lion will roar in the forest when he hath no prey, implying the lion roars only when hunting.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:5, can a bird fall into a snare if there is no gin for it?
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 3:5 explains that a bird cannot fall into a snare if there is no gin (trap) for it, indicating traps must be set to catch prey.

questions.question: What will happen when a trumpet is blown in the city, according to Amos 3:6?
options: The people will be afraid
The people will rejoice
The people will ignore it
The people will go to sleep
questions.correctAnswer: The people will be afraid
questions.explanation: Amos 3:6 asks if people will not be afraid when a trumpet is blown, implying that the trumpet causes fear and warning.

questions.question: What does Amos 3:7 say about the Lord GOD and His servants the prophets?
options: He reveals His secrets to them
He hides His plans from them
He punishes them
He ignores them
questions.correctAnswer: He reveals His secrets to them
questions.explanation: Amos 3:7 states that the Lord GOD does nothing without revealing His secret to His servants the prophets.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 3:8 says that the Lord GOD has spoken and none can prophesy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 3:8 says the Lord GOD hath spoken, and who can but prophesy? meaning everyone who hears must prophesy.

questions.question: Where does Amos 3:9 instruct to publish the message?
options: In the palaces at Ashdod and the land of Egypt
In the temples of Jerusalem
In the markets of Babylon
In the cities of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: In the palaces at Ashdod and the land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Amos 3:9 commands publishing in the palaces of Ashdod and Egypt, calling for assembly on the mountains of Samaria.

questions.question: What do the people in Samaria not know how to do, according to Amos 3:10?
options: Do right
Sing praises
Build houses
Plant crops
questions.correctAnswer: Do right
questions.explanation: Amos 3:10 says the people know not to do right and store up violence and robbery in their palaces.

questions.question: What will happen to the palaces, as stated in Amos 3:11?
options: They shall be spoiled
They shall be decorated
They shall be doubled
They shall be preserved
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be spoiled
questions.explanation: Amos 3:11 says an adversary will bring down their strength and spoil their palaces.

questions.question: Complete the comparison from Amos 3:12: 'As the shepherd taketh out of the mouth of the lion two legs, or a piece of an ear; so shall the children of Israel be taken out that dwell in ______.'
options: Samaria in the corner of a bed, and in Damascus in a couch
Jerusalem on the mountaintop
Egypt by the river banks
Babylon in the plains
questions.correctAnswer: Samaria in the corner of a bed, and in Damascus in a couch
questions.explanation: Amos 3:12 compares the partial rescue of Israel's children in Samaria and Damascus to a shepherd rescuing parts of a sheep from a lion.

questions.question: In Amos 3:14, what will happen to the horns of the altar at Bethel?
options: They shall be cut off and fall to the ground
They shall be made of gold
They shall be guarded by angels
They shall be hidden
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be cut off and fall to the ground
questions.explanation: Amos 3:14 states that on the day of visiting Israel's transgressions, the horns of the altar at Bethel will be cut off and fall.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 3:15 prophesies that the houses of ivory will endure forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 3:15 declares that houses of ivory shall perish and great houses shall have an end.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:13, who is instructed to hear and testify?
options: The house of Jacob
The priests of Bethel
The elders of Samaria
The people of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Jacob
questions.explanation: Amos 3:13 calls the house of Jacob to hear and testify as commanded by the Lord GOD.

medium.title: Amos Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Amos Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with understanding God's discipline in their life. Based on Amos 3:2, what biblical truth would you share about God’s relationship with His people and discipline?
options: God disciplines because He has chosen and knows His people intimately
God ignores the sins of His people because He loves them
God disciplines all nations equally without distinction
God punishes without revealing His reasons
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines because He has chosen and knows His people intimately
questions.explanation: Amos 3:2 shows that God has a special knowledge of Israel and therefore will punish them for their sins. This highlights God's loving discipline for those He knows and has chosen. Verses 3:1, 3:7, and 3:14 also support the idea of God’s purposeful actions toward His people.

questions.question: How does Amos 3:3 teach about the importance of agreement and unity in Christian fellowship and service?
options: Two cannot walk together unless they are agreed
Agreement is optional in Christian fellowship
Disagreements strengthen Christian service
Walking separately is better for spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Two cannot walk together unless they are agreed
questions.explanation: Amos 3:3 states clearly that agreement is necessary for fellowship and joint action. This teaches the importance of unity for effective ministry and mutual support. Verses 3:7 and 3:8 emphasize God’s communication and prophecy in unity with His servants.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to act unjustly in business. Based on Amos 3:10, what principle about integrity and righteousness can encourage them?
options: Those who do not do right store up violence and robbery
Success is achieved by any means necessary
God is indifferent to how wealth is gained
Righteousness is optional in business
questions.correctAnswer: Those who do not do right store up violence and robbery
questions.explanation: Amos 3:10 warns that failing to do right leads to violence and robbery. This calls believers to integrity in their work and stewardship. Verses 3:2 and 3:11 also speak of consequences for injustice and wickedness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 3:7, God reveals His plans only to the general public, not His prophets.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Amos 3:7 clearly states that God reveals His secrets to His servants, the prophets, not just to the public. This emphasizes the role of prophets as God’s messengers. Verses 3:8 and 3:13 also highlight the prophetic role.

questions.question: How does Amos 3:6 teach believers about God’s sovereignty over events that cause fear or calamity in a community?
options: Evil in a city happens only because the LORD permits it
Calamities are random and not under God’s control
God is unaware of the troubles in a city
People should not fear when warnings are given
questions.correctAnswer: Evil in a city happens only because the LORD permits it
questions.explanation: Amos 3:6 teaches that God is sovereign over fearful events and calamities, and that He allows them for His purposes. This calls believers to trust God’s control in trials. Verses 3:2 and 3:11 reinforce God’s active involvement in judgment.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about sharing the Gospel because they feel unheard. What encouragement does Amos 3:8 offer about proclaiming God’s word?
options: When the Lord speaks, it compels prophecy and fear among people
Proclaiming God’s word is optional and often ignored
Fear is a sign that God’s word is not true
God’s message is only for a select few
questions.correctAnswer: When the Lord speaks, it compels prophecy and fear among people
questions.explanation: Amos 3:8 compares God’s word to a lion’s roar, which demands attention and prophecy. This encourages believers to boldly share God’s truth. Verses 3:7 and 3:13 also affirm God’s revelation through prophets.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:12, what does the imagery of a shepherd rescuing a sheep from a lion teach about God’s protection and judgment?
options: God delivers some but judgment will come to those who persist in sin
All people will be delivered without exception
God ignores the plight of His people
Judgment is random and without cause
questions.correctAnswer: God delivers some but judgment will come to those who persist in sin
questions.explanation: Amos 3:12 uses vivid imagery to show that while some are rescued, judgment will come on many due to sin. This encourages perseverance and repentance. Verses 3:11 and 3:15 also warn of the consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Amos 3:14 warns that when God visits the transgressions of Israel, He will also visit the altars of ________."
options: Bethel
Jerusalem
Samaria
Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel
questions.explanation: Amos 3:14 specifically mentions Bethel as the place whose altars will be cut off when God judges Israel’s sins. This highlights that religious places are not exempt from God’s justice. Verses 3:2 and 3:10 also stress judgment for sins.

questions.question: How does Amos 3:15 illustrate the consequences of pride and materialism in the life of believers?
options: Houses of ivory and great houses will perish as a consequence
Material wealth guarantees God’s favor
Pride leads to eternal blessings
Possessions are permanent and secure
questions.correctAnswer: Houses of ivory and great houses will perish as a consequence
questions.explanation: Amos 3:15 speaks of the destruction of luxurious homes, warning against pride and reliance on material wealth. This calls believers to humility and contentment. Verses 3:10 and 3:11 also warn of downfall due to injustice and sin.

questions.question: True or False: Amos 3:4 uses the metaphor of a lion roaring only when it has prey, teaching that God’s warnings come with purpose.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 3:4 uses the lion’s roar to illustrate that God’s warnings and judgments have a definite cause and purpose, encouraging believers to heed His warnings carefully. Verses 3:5 and 3:6 also use natural imagery to teach about God’s purposeful actions.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and attentiveness to God can be drawn from Amos 3:7?
options: God reveals His plans to His servants, so we should listen and be attentive
God hides His plans from everyone equally
Prayer is unnecessary because God does not communicate
Only kings receive God’s secrets
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals His plans to His servants, so we should listen and be attentive
questions.explanation: Amos 3:7 highlights that God communicates His plans through prophets, implying believers should be attentive in prayer and spiritual listening. Verses 3:8 and 3:13 reinforce the prophetic role in revealing God’s will.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by the injustice around them. Based on Amos 3:9, what encouragement can you give about God’s awareness of oppression?
options: God calls people to witness the tumults and oppression, showing He is aware and concerned
God ignores oppression in distant lands
Oppression is normal and God accepts it
Only the oppressed should speak out, not others
questions.correctAnswer: God calls people to witness the tumults and oppression, showing He is aware and concerned
questions.explanation: Amos 3:9 commands the public proclamation of the turmoil and oppression, indicating God’s active awareness and judgment. Verses 3:10 and 3:11 also emphasize God’s response to injustice.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:1, what is the significance of God's calling Israel ‘the whole family which I brought up from the land of Egypt’ in terms of faith and obedience?
options: God’s covenant relationship calls for Israel’s faithfulness and obedience
Israel is just like any other nation without special calling
God’s relationship with Israel is based on their power
Israel is free to ignore God’s commands
questions.correctAnswer: God’s covenant relationship calls for Israel’s faithfulness and obedience
questions.explanation: Amos 3:1 reminds Israel of their special covenant as God’s chosen family, implying a call to faithfulness and obedience. Verses 3:2 and 3:14 reinforce accountability based on this relationship.

questions.question: How does Amos 3:11 teach about the consequences of persistent sin and the need for repentance?
options: An adversary will come and bring down strength if people do not repent
God will overlook persistent sin without consequence
Sin has no effect on a nation’s strength
Repentance is optional for believers
questions.correctAnswer: An adversary will come and bring down strength if people do not repent
questions.explanation: Amos 3:11 warns that enemies will overtake the land and spoil palaces because of sin, highlighting the necessity of repentance. Verses 3:2 and 3:15 also describe consequences of sin and judgment.

questions.question: A believer wants to cultivate humility and contentment. How does Amos 3:15’s message about the destruction of 'houses of ivory' and 'great houses' reinforce this virtue?
options: Prideful reliance on wealth is temporary and leads to downfall
Wealth guarantees protection from God
Contentment is unrelated to material possessions
God blesses those with many possessions
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful reliance on wealth is temporary and leads to downfall
questions.explanation: Amos 3:15 warns that luxurious possessions will perish, teaching believers to cultivate humility and contentment rather than pride in wealth. Verses 3:10 and 3:12 also warn against storing violence and reliance on strength.

hard.title: Amos Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Amos Chapter 3.

questions.question: In Amos 3:3, the rhetorical question 'Can two walk together, except they be agreed?' primarily illustrates which theological principle?
options: The necessity of covenantal harmony between God and Israel
The importance of social unity among the tribes of Israel
The futility of alliances with foreign nations
The inevitability of divine judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The necessity of covenantal harmony between God and Israel
questions.explanation: Amos 3:3 uses the metaphor of walking together only when agreed to emphasize the indispensable harmony required in the covenant relationship between God and Israel.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the lion roaring in Amos 3:4 and 3:8 function as a typological symbol in biblical literature?
options: It symbolizes God's impending judgment and authority
It represents Israel's strength and kingship
It denotes the adversaries of Israel
It reflects the peaceful nature of God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's impending judgment and authority
questions.explanation: The lion's roar in Amos 3:4 and 3:8 typifies divine authority and judgment, a motif echoed in other Scriptures such as Hosea and Revelation, where the lion symbolizes God's power to judge.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominantly employed in Amos 3:5 when it asks if a bird falls into a snare where no trap exists?
options: Rhetorical question
Chiasm
Metaphor
Parable
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical question
questions.explanation: Amos 3:5 uses rhetorical questions to emphasize the inevitability of consequences when traps (judgments) are set, underscoring the certainty of Israel's punishment.

questions.question: In Amos 3:6, the text states, 'Shall there be evil in a city, and the LORD hath not done it?' How should this be understood in the broader biblical context?
options: God sovereignly permits or ordains judgment as part of divine justice
God is the source of all evil and sin
Evil is independent of God's will
God punishes only the innocent
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly permits or ordains judgment as part of divine justice
questions.explanation: Amos 3:6 reflects the theological concept of divine sovereignty over calamity and judgment, a theme consistent with other prophetic books like Isaiah and Jeremiah.

questions.question: Amos 3:7 declares, 'Surely the Lord GOD will do nothing, but he revealeth his secret unto his servants the prophets.' What does this reveal about the role of prophets?
options: Prophets are God's chosen intermediaries revealing divine plans
Prophets act independently of God's will
Prophets only foretell natural events
Prophets are merely political advisors
questions.correctAnswer: Prophets are God's chosen intermediaries revealing divine plans
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the prophetic office as God’s mouthpiece, revealing His intentions beforehand, establishing their authority and divine inspiration.

questions.question: The command in Amos 3:9 to 'Publish in the palaces at Ashdod, and in the palaces in the land of Egypt' serves what historical or cultural purpose?
options: To warn foreign nations of Israel's downfall
To celebrate Israel's military victories
To invite allies to a festival
To request military aid from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To warn foreign nations of Israel's downfall
questions.explanation: Amos 3:9 indicates a public proclamation to neighboring powers, signifying that Israel's turmoil and judgment are known beyond its borders, reflecting the geopolitical tensions of the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'You only have I known of all the families of the earth' in Amos 3:2 in terms of covenant theology?
options: It emphasizes Israel's unique election and responsibility
It indicates exclusivity of worship practices
It denotes geographical separation from other nations
It affirms Israel's political dominance
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Israel's unique election and responsibility
questions.explanation: This phrase in Amos 3:2 reflects Israel’s special covenant relationship with God, which entails both privilege and accountability for their iniquities.

questions.question: Amos 3:12 uses the metaphor of a shepherd rescuing parts of a prey from a lion’s mouth. What does this typify in the prophetic message?
options: The partial preservation of Israel amid judgment
The complete destruction of Israel
The restoration of Israel's monarchy
The defeat of Israel’s enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The partial preservation of Israel amid judgment
questions.explanation: The metaphor in Amos 3:12 foreshadows that although Israel will face severe judgment, a remnant will be preserved, a concept echoed throughout prophetic literature.

questions.question: In Amos 3:14, the phrase 'the horns of the altar shall be cut off' symbolizes what in the ancient Israelite religious context?
options: The removal of access to atonement and protection
The enhancement of altar sacrifices
The construction of new temples
The establishment of peace offerings
questions.correctAnswer: The removal of access to atonement and protection
questions.explanation: The altar’s horns were symbolic of refuge and divine protection; cutting them off (Amos 3:14) indicates the loss of God’s favor and the cessation of atonement privileges.

questions.question: Amos 3:10 states, 'they know not to do right... who store up violence and robbery in their palaces.' What social critique is Amos making here?
options: Condemning the corruption and injustice of the ruling elite
Praising Israel's wealth accumulation
Encouraging the building of grand palaces
Promoting violent resistance against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Condemning the corruption and injustice of the ruling elite
questions.explanation: Amos 3:10 indicts the elite who exploit others and store violence, highlighting themes of social justice pervasive throughout the prophetic corpus.

questions.question: True or False: According to Amos 3:15, the destruction will affect both luxurious and ordinary houses in Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Amos 3:15 explicitly states that 'houses of ivory shall perish, and the great houses shall have an end,' indicating that both luxurious and presumably ordinary dwellings will be destroyed.

questions.question: What is the significance of God bringing down Israel's strength and spoiling their palaces as mentioned in Amos 3:11, in the context of ancient Near Eastern power dynamics?
options: It symbolizes the loss of political and military power
It refers to the construction of new palaces
It indicates a trade embargo
It celebrates Israel's independence
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the loss of political and military power
questions.explanation: The imagery in Amos 3:11 reflects the common ancient Near Eastern motif of divine judgment resulting in political collapse and loss of royal prestige.

questions.question: In Amos 3:13, the phrase 'Hear ye, and testify in the house of Jacob' serves what purpose within the prophetic call?
options: To urge witnesses to confirm Israel's guilt
To invite neighboring nations to worship
To announce a festival in Jacob’s house
To propose a political alliance
questions.correctAnswer: To urge witnesses to confirm Israel's guilt
questions.explanation: Amos 3:13 calls for testimony within Israel (‘house of Jacob’), a legal and prophetic act to confirm the nation's transgressions before God.

questions.question: How does the theme of divine revelation in Amos 3:7 relate to New Testament teachings on prophecy and revelation?
options: It parallels the concept of the Spirit revealing truth to believers
It contradicts the idea of prophecy in the New Testament
It limits revelation only to the Old Testament prophets
It refers exclusively to dreams and visions
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels the concept of the Spirit revealing truth to believers
questions.explanation: Amos 3:7’s emphasis on God revealing secrets aligns with New Testament teachings on the Holy Spirit guiding believers into all truth (John 16:13).

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated use of rhetorical questions throughout Amos 3, such as in verses 3 to 6?
options: To provoke reflection on the certainty of God's judgment
To confuse the audience
To offer multiple theological options
To downplay the seriousness of Israel's sins
questions.correctAnswer: To provoke reflection on the certainty of God's judgment
questions.explanation: The rhetorical questions serve as a literary device emphasizing the inevitability of consequences when covenantal obligations are broken, highlighting divine justice.

theological.title: Amos Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Amos Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Amos 3, why does God say He will punish Israel specifically?
options: Because they only have He known among all families of the earth
Because they worship other gods
Because they failed to build the temple
Because they refused to fight their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Because they only have He known among all families of the earth
questions.explanation: Amos 3:2 explains that God has a unique covenant relationship with Israel, knowing them exclusively among the families of the earth, which grounds His decision to punish them for their iniquities. This reflects God's covenantal justice seen also in Deuteronomy 7:6 and Hosea 2:23, and aligns with New Testament teaching on God's chosen people in Romans 11:2 and 1 Peter 2:9.

questions.question: What does Amos 3:3 teach about agreement and fellowship?
options: Two cannot walk together unless they agree
Two must always follow different paths
Two should avoid each other to prevent conflict
Two walk together regardless of agreement
questions.correctAnswer: Two cannot walk together unless they agree
questions.explanation: Amos 3:3 uses the metaphor of walking together to illustrate that fellowship and partnership require agreement. This principle parallels Jesus' teaching on unity in John 17:21, Paul's admonition about being unequally yoked in 2 Corinthians 6:14, and Proverbs 13:20 on wise companionship.

questions.question: In Amos 3:6, what role does the trumpet blowing in the city serve?
options: To alert the people and cause fear about impending evil
To celebrate a festival
To call people to worship
To announce a king's arrival
questions.correctAnswer: To alert the people and cause fear about impending evil
questions.explanation: Amos 3:6 indicates that a trumpet sound in the city is meant to warn and induce fear because of coming evil, demonstrating God's sovereign judgment. This is consistent with biblical uses of trumpets as warnings in Exodus 19:16, Joel 2:1, and Revelation 8:6-13, where trumpet blasts signal divine intervention.

questions.question: What does Amos 3:7 reveal about God’s communication with humanity?
options: God reveals His plans only through His prophets
God never reveals His intentions
God communicates only through angels
God reveals secrets through dreams exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals His plans only through His prophets
questions.explanation: Amos 3:7 teaches that God does nothing without first revealing His secret to His servants, the prophets. This underscores the prophetic office as God’s communicative agent, in line with Numbers 12:6, 1 Corinthians 14:29, Hebrews 1:1, and Revelation 1:1.

questions.question: How does Amos 3:8 describe the effect of the Lord God’s proclamation?
options: The Lord God’s roar causes fear and compels prophecy
The Lord God’s roar is ignored by all
The Lord God’s roar leads to silence
The Lord God’s roar is a call to battle
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord God’s roar causes fear and compels prophecy
questions.explanation: Amos 3:8 likens God’s word to a lion’s roar that instills fear and compels prophecy. This metaphor aligns with Isaiah 42:13 where God is depicted as a roaring lion and with New Testament references to the prophetic role empowered by God’s Spirit, e.g., Acts 2:17 and 1 Peter 1:10-12.

questions.question: What is the significance of the reference to Ashdod and Egypt in Amos 3:9?
options: To proclaim judgment to foreign nations aware of Israel’s turmoil
To invite these nations to join Israel’s worship
To celebrate peace treaties with these nations
To praise these nations for their righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: To proclaim judgment to foreign nations aware of Israel’s turmoil
questions.explanation: Amos 3:9 commands the proclamation of Israel’s internal disorder to foreign powers like Ashdod and Egypt, signifying that Israel’s judgment is public and international. This reflects the biblical theme of nations witnessing God’s justice, as seen in Ezekiel 36:20, Jeremiah 25:15, and Psalm 9:16.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:10, what sin are the people of Israel accused of?
options: Storing up violence and robbery in their palaces
Worshiping idols publicly
Refusing to build altars
Neglecting the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Storing up violence and robbery in their palaces
questions.explanation: Amos 3:10 indicts Israel for accumulating violence and robbery, implying systemic injustice and corruption. This is consistent with prophetic condemnations in Isaiah 1:23, Micah 6:10-12, Jeremiah 22:3, and Jesus’ denunciation of unrighteous leaders in Matthew 23:25-28.

questions.question: What consequence does Amos 3:11 predict for Israel because of their sins?
options: An adversary will surround the land and plunder their strength and palaces
They will be blessed with peace and prosperity
Their enemies will become their allies
Their enemies will be destroyed immediately
questions.correctAnswer: An adversary will surround the land and plunder their strength and palaces
questions.explanation: Amos 3:11 foretells that Israel’s enemies will encircle them and strip away their power and wealth. This judgment theme is echoed in Leviticus 26:17, 2 Kings 17:3-6, Jeremiah 25:9, and Luke 21:20-24 concerning the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness.

questions.question: In Amos 3:12, what imagery is used to describe Israel’s deliverance by God?
options: Like a shepherd rescuing a lamb from a lion’s mouth
Like a king defeating his enemies in battle
Like a farmer harvesting grain
Like a fisherman catching fish
questions.correctAnswer: Like a shepherd rescuing a lamb from a lion’s mouth
questions.explanation: Amos 3:12 uses the metaphor of a shepherd snatching a lamb from a lion’s mouth to depict God’s rescue of the remnant of Israel, emphasizing His care and power. This resonates with Psalm 23:4, Ezekiel 34:11-16, Isaiah 40:11, and John 10:11 where God or Christ is portrayed as the Good Shepherd.

questions.question: What is the call to action in Amos 3:13?
options: Hear and testify in the house of Jacob
Build altars to the Lord
Offer sacrifices to appease God
Go into exile willingly
questions.correctAnswer: Hear and testify in the house of Jacob
questions.explanation: Amos 3:13 commands the people to hear God’s word and bear witness within Israel, highlighting the responsibility of public confession and testimony. This aligns with the prophetic call in Isaiah 43:10, Ezekiel 2:3-5, and the apostolic mandate in Acts 1:8 and Romans 10:14-15.

questions.question: What does Amos 3:14 say will happen to the altars of Bethel?
options: The horns of the altar will be cut off and fall to the ground
The altars will be sanctified and preserved
The altars will be covered with gold
The altars will be relocated to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The horns of the altar will be cut off and fall to the ground
questions.explanation: Amos 3:14 predicts the destruction of Bethel’s altars, symbolized by the loss of the altar’s horns, which were sacred and signified protection. This judgment theme is consistent with Hosea 10:8, Jeremiah 48:13, 1 Kings 13:2, and Hebrews 10:26-27 where altars and sacrifices are judged for idolatry.

questions.question: According to Amos 3:15, what will happen to the houses of ivory and great houses?
options: They shall perish and come to an end
They shall be filled with prosperity
They shall be places of worship
They shall be fortified against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They shall perish and come to an end
questions.explanation: Amos 3:15 pronounces that luxurious homes, symbolized by ivory and great houses, will be destroyed as part of God’s judgment. This reflects the biblical theme of God opposing the proud and wealthy who oppress others, found in Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 3:14-15, James 5:1-6, and Luke 12:15-21.

questions.question: What theological truth about divine sovereignty is taught in Amos 3:6?
options: Evil in a city occurs only by the LORD’s permission
Human decisions alone cause evil
Evil happens randomly without God’s knowledge
God allows evil but does not cause it
questions.correctAnswer: Evil in a city occurs only by the LORD’s permission
questions.explanation: Amos 3:6 affirms God’s sovereign control over all events, including evil, teaching that nothing happens apart from His will. This aligns with Job 1:12, Isaiah 45:7, Lamentations 3:37-38, and Romans 8:28, emphasizing God’s providential governance.

questions.question: How does Amos 3:4 use the analogy of a lion’s behavior to communicate a spiritual truth?
options: A lion does not roar unless it has taken prey, symbolizing purposeful divine judgment
A lion always roars to declare its presence
A lion roars to attract other animals
A lion roars to signal peace
questions.correctAnswer: A lion does not roar unless it has taken prey, symbolizing purposeful divine judgment
questions.explanation: Amos 3:4 compares God’s roar to a lion’s roar, emphasizing that God’s judgments are purposeful and justified, not arbitrary. This imagery is echoed in Hosea 11:10, Jeremiah 25:30-31, Revelation 5:5, and Isaiah 31:4 where God acts decisively against sin.

questions.question: What does Amos 3:5 teach about the inevitability of consequences?
options: One cannot be caught in a snare without there being a trap
Traps often fail to catch their prey
God does not allow consequences to fall on the innocent
Consequences are random and unpredictable
questions.correctAnswer: One cannot be caught in a snare without there being a trap
questions.explanation: Amos 3:5 uses the example of a bird falling into a snare to teach that consequences are not accidental but result from deliberate causes. This principle aligns with retributive justice found in Proverbs 1:10-15, Galatians 6:7, Jeremiah 17:10, and Romans 2:6.
